Award.AwardTitle: Recent Methods in Operator Theory; October 15-16, 2015; Memphis, TN
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the conference "Recent Methods in Operator Theory" that will be held on October 15 and 16, 2015, on the campus of the University of Memphis.

This conference is a satellite event to the meeting of the American Mathematical Society's Southeastern Section that will take place in October 2015. The conference will focus attention on recent methods and advances in operator theory via a series of expository lectures on long-standing open problems in operator theory, state-of-the-art techniques, and important recent contributions to the field. The goals of the workshop are the following: (1) to disseminate mainstream trends, state-of-the-art techniques, and recent advances in operator theory to a large group of female and underrepresented graduate students and early career mathematicians; (2) to create a social environment among a diverse level of participants encouraging fruitful discussions of mathematical ideas and sharing of promising research; and (3) to initiate a network of support among participants for future research interaction.The conference program provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project consisted on two parts: A workshop on October 15-16 (2015) and a conference on April 17-18 (2017).

The workshop was on Recent Methods in Operator Theory and gathered a group of more than 50 participants. The list of participants included leading researchers in Operator Theory, early career mathematicians and graduate students. There were six plenary lectures, a general audience talk and a poster session. Plenary lectures were given by an international group of female mathematicians with highly respected research work in operator theory and well recognized communication[FB1]   skills.  The plenary talks were geared to advanced graduate students and early career mathematicians. The poster session had 12 participants. The lectures, posters, meals and informal periods for discussion promoted an active and friendly environment very much appreciated by everyone present. A group of mathematicians evaluated anonymously all posters and three of those posters received an award. Presentations, abstracts and posters are available at the web location: http://www.memphis.edu/msci/2015prmo/

The conference was on Methods in Operator Theory and Applications. It had 13 presentations and 25 participants. Abstracts and program schedule are available at the website:http://www.memphis.edu/msci/news/methods-operator-theory-applications-conference.php

The main goal of these two meetings was to create an environment where participants could learn about recent advances and state-of-the-art techniques in Operator Theory. The workshop presentations gave an introductory and broad view of several active research areas within Operator Theory. It also provided background information for the presentations given at the Fall Southeastern-AMS Special Session (October 17-18, 2015) on Advances in Operator Theory and Applications, in Memory of James Jamison, co-organized by the Fernanda Botelho (University of Memphis) and T.S.S.R.K. Rao (ISI, Bangalore, India).   

This combination provided a unique enriching experience for graduate students and early career mathematicians.  Participants had ample chances to meet other students and young mathematicians, interact with senior scholars and recognized research.  

 

As follow-up of these events, Fernanda Botelho was invited to give research talks at the Kyoto Institute and Nara Chamber of Commerce (Japan - October 2016);  OTOA 16 in ISI-Bangalore (India-December 2016); and Preservers Everywhere in Szeged (Hungary-June 2017).

The Contemporary Mathematics volume  687, entitled  Methods in Operator Theory  was published by AMS in April 2017, and co-edited by Fernanda Botelho, Raena King and T.S.S.R.K. Rao.  This volume contains 21 invited research and survey articles featuring a selection of topics from the presentations at the workshop and follow-up AMS Special Session.
